sub_title: Research Associate, Specialist in Earth observation, remote sensing, O&G emissions,   spatial analysis and data science
summary:
I am an objective-driven and detail-oriented person that makes the observation of the Earth my passion and my career. I have lived and studied in three different countries (Spain, UK and The Netherlands) and this has enriched my personality and the way I work and relate with others.
Technically sounded with a broad knowledge in remote sensing and environment.




                                                                       Extraordinary things are often done by ordinary people. . .

projects: [{'title': 'Detecting methane emissions from Space', 'date': {'start': {'month': 10, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}, 'end': {'month': 10, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'description': None, 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Dr. Ir. Raquel', 'last_name': 'Serrano Calvo', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Research Associate, Specialist in Earth observation, remote sensing, O&G emissions,   spatial analysis and data science'}]}, {'title': 'Understanding hydrocarbon impacts on vegetation and detection with remote sensing', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2016}, 'end': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'description': ' Looking at the physical impacts of hydrocarbons on soils and how that impacts on vegetation. By using remote sensing we hope to be able to detect the impacts of hydrocarbons on the vegetation at a much earlier stage, and possibly develop methods for detecting hydrocarbon contamination / spills from aircraft- and satellite-based remote sensors to aid detection, response and restoration following hydrocarbon releases.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Dr. Ir. Raquel', 'last_name': 'Serrano Calvo', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Research Associate, Specialist in Earth observation, remote sensing, O&G emissions,   spatial analysis and data science'}]}, {'title': 'Prediction of collapsing karstic events by integrating NDVI Index from Landsat-7 ETM+ imagery and GIS tools. Application to the zone between Salisbury and Winchester, United Kingdom.', 'date': {'start': {'month': 3, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': 11, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'description': 'The collapsing events associated to karst is an important geohazard affecting vast zones of the United Kingdom. Areas such as the south of England has a high collapsing occurrence rate increasing the risk for the population. To mitigate this problem, some techniques that can characterize the affected areas were developed in previous research. \nThe application of the GIS and geodata help to detect possible sinkhole areas, but this is not sufficient due to there has not been implemented yet a method to monitor the behaviour of the terrain before and after the collapsing event. \n In United Kingdom the land use categorized as agricultural or forestry is 75%, this fact could hinder the prediction process of possible sinkholes due to the difficulties of doing geology in areas with a high level vegetation development. However, the vegetation is susceptible to hydrological and terrain changes which is well known as “stress vegetation”. In this direction, satellite images can add this component with the NDVI index which can provide information about the vegetation stress related to the soil behavior. In addition, the monitoring of subsidence with satellite imagery can open another way to advise local authorities and the community of collapsing events and therefore, increase the reaction time and mitigate the consequences.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Dr. Ir. Raquel', 'last_name': 'Serrano Calvo', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Research Associate, Specialist in Earth observation, remote sensing, O&G emissions,   spatial analysis and data science'}]}, {'title': 'Study of the evolution of the snowpack in the Pyrenees (winter 2009-2010) from MODIS images applied to hydrological modeling', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}}, 'description': 'In the hydrological water reserves calculus from the snowmaking is essential the knowledge of the snow coverage to estimate the volume of water stored. Obtaining these data from with in-situ measurements in field trips and subsequent interpolation provides a coverage with insufficient quality and a high economic cost. For this reason, the study of snow cover from satellite imaginery together with a Digital Terrain Model provides a digital mapping of the snow coverage with lower costs, data inaccessible areas and a daily check thanks to the use of MODIS images, the snow cover. This dissertation proposes the use of remote sensing techniques for mapping of snow coverage in the Pyrenees as well as the study of its temporal and spatial evolution along the period comprised between November 2009 - May 2010 with a special attention to the orientation, slope and height of the terrain.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Dr. Ir. Raquel', 'last_name': 'Serrano Calvo', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Research Associate, Specialist in Earth observation, remote sensing, O&G emissions,   spatial analysis and data science'}]}]
